content.raw: Are you planning to also move entity/component creation and component deletion to the Run loop so that all actions behave the same way?
content.html: Are you planning to also move entity/component creation and component deletion to the Run loop so that all actions behave the same way?

content.raw: The reason I'm asking is that if an entity is created in the middle of an iteration, it may be processed by some systems but not others, so I think it makes sense to follow the deletion pattern introduced in this PR.
content.html: The reason I'm asking is that if an entity is created in the middle of an iteration, it may be processed by some systems but not others, so I think it makes sense to follow the deletion pattern introduced in this PR.

content.raw: Good point. Right now the SimulationRunner has a `CreateEntities` function that is called once when an SDF file is loaded. However, there is nothing preventing a System from creating new entities and components. This might not be a functional problem, but it could be considered an inconsistency between creation and deletion.  We can change the behavior, but I don't think it's high priority right now unless you can think of a failure case. I've create issue #6 for this.
content.html: Good point. Right now the SimulationRunner has a CreateEntities function that is called once when an SDF file is loaded. However, there is nothing preventing a System from creating new entities and components. This might not be a functional problem, but it could be considered an inconsistency between creation and deletion. We can change the behavior, but I don't think it's high priority right now unless you can think of a failure case. I've create issue #6 for this.

content.raw: This logic could be moved to the `View` class as a `EraseEntity` function, just like there's an `AddEntity`. This way, the manager doesn't need to know its internals, like how it stores entities and components.
content.html: This logic could be moved to the View class as a EraseEntity function, just like there's an AddEntity. This way, the manager doesn't need to know its internals, like how it stores entities and components.

content.raw:
I have mixed feelings about giving a component type special meaning within the server. How can entities which don't have a name component be deleted? I propose this function takes `EntityId`.

Also note that:

* we're currently not enforcing unique names
* the name within the component is the "local" name and doesn't contain the scope of the entity - so expect many component names to equal "link", for example
* we may want to support URIs, which work more like scoped names

Instead, I'd propose we add a system (i.e. `FactorySystem`), which provides Ignition Transport services for insertion and deletion. Since it is user-facing, it would make sense that it handles specifically entities which have a name component. Another benefit is that the system can be aware of the entity hierarchy, so deleting a model will also delete its links.

The tricky thing with the asynchronous handling of deletion is that the service wouldn't be able to return to the caller a valid answer as to whether the entity has been successfully deleted (unless it waits for an iteration to check).
content.html:
I have mixed feelings about giving a component type special meaning within the server. How can entities which don't have a name component be deleted? I propose this function takes EntityId.

Also note that:

  • we're currently not enforcing unique names
  • the name within the component is the "local" name and doesn't contain the scope of the entity - so expect many component names to equal "link", for example
  • we may want to support URIs, which work more like scoped names

Instead, I'd propose we add a system (i.e. FactorySystem), which provides Ignition Transport services for insertion and deletion. Since it is user-facing, it would make sense that it handles specifically entities which have a name component. Another benefit is that the system can be aware of the entity hierarchy, so deleting a model will also delete its links.

The tricky thing with the asynchronous handling of deletion is that the service wouldn't be able to return to the caller a valid answer as to whether the entity has been successfully deleted (unless it waits for an iteration to check).

content.raw: Good notes, but all of those things seem like features that can be added and do not make this function invalid.
content.html: Good notes, but all of those things seem like features that can be added and do not make this function invalid.

content.raw: What is the use case for this function?
content.html: What is the use case for this function?

content.raw: The user should have a function that they can call to remove an entity based on a name.
content.html: The user should have a function that they can call to remove an entity based on a name.

content.raw:
Who is that user? If it's a simulation end-user, I think it makes sense to use the name as it is user-friendly. But I also think that same user would expect functionality like deleting an entity will delete all its children, are we adding this here in the future?

If it's a developer, I think `EntityId` makes more sense. As I mentioned earlier, not all entities are guaranteed to have a name component, how to delete those?
content.html:
Who is that user? If it's a simulation end-user, I think it makes sense to use the name as it is user-friendly. But I also think that same user would expect functionality like deleting an entity will delete all its children, are we adding this here in the future?

If it's a developer, I think EntityId makes more sense. As I mentioned earlier, not all entities are guaranteed to have a name component, how to delete those?

content.raw:
It's fine that not all entities have a name component, you just won't be able to delete them through this function.

A function that erases based on ID can be added, and a function that deletes all children based on some criteria can be added. 

Is there something broken or wrong with this function?
content.html:
It's fine that not all entities have a name component, you just won't be able to delete them through this function.

A function that erases based on ID can be added, and a function that deletes all children based on some criteria can be added.

Is there something broken or wrong with this function?

content.raw:
It just feels to me that we're giving special treatment to a specific component, and manipulating it from outside a system, thus "breaking" the ECS abstraction. The server is also aware of the component's internals, like how it contains a string.

I also wasn't sure of the use case, and it's still not clear to me if this will be useful for developers/users in the long run. But I can wait until we get a clear picture of how they will be expected to delete entities.

Finally, a more generic alternative could be a templated function which erases any component type by value.

In any case, as you said, this doesn't "break" anything concrete, so I think we can leave it in the way it is - but we may want at least to make it delete all entities which have the given name, for completeness.
content.html:
It just feels to me that we're giving special treatment to a specific component, and manipulating it from outside a system, thus "breaking" the ECS abstraction. The server is also aware of the component's internals, like how it contains a string.

I also wasn't sure of the use case, and it's still not clear to me if this will be useful for developers/users in the long run. But I can wait until we get a clear picture of how they will be expected to delete entities.

Finally, a more generic alternative could be a templated function which erases any component type by value.

In any case, as you said, this doesn't "break" anything concrete, so I think we can leave it in the way it is - but we may want at least to make it delete all entities which have the given name, for completeness.

content.raw:
Adding in Erase using an ID: f6963bd. It still needs work.

I don't see this as breaking ECS. Adding inheritance is one way to break the goals of ECS.  There is nothing wrong with adding functionality, like deleting or accessing entities based on a name. Our use case makes heavy use of names, and we should give users access to entities based on that fact.

Gazebo is currently lacking an API that provides introspection and manipulation of the internals. Imagine you use gazebo as a library and load a world file. How do you get access to the entities? The Server API will likely grow quite a bit in order to support downstream users.
content.html:
Adding in Erase using an ID: f6963bd. It still needs work.

I don't see this as breaking ECS. Adding inheritance is one way to break the goals of ECS. There is nothing wrong with adding functionality, like deleting or accessing entities based on a name. Our use case makes heavy use of names, and we should give users access to entities based on that fact.

Gazebo is currently lacking an API that provides introspection and manipulation of the internals. Imagine you use gazebo as a library and load a world file. How do you get access to the entities? The Server API will likely grow quite a bit in order to support downstream users.

content.raw:
Got it. I just worry that the server / simulation runner classes may end up with a really large API to access / change components, and having too many responsibilities beyond serving / running simulations.

But we can iterate and see if this becomes a problem or not.

Got it. I just worry that the server / simulation runner classes may end up with a really large API to access / change components, and having too many responsibilities beyond serving / running simulations.

But we can iterate and see if this becomes a problem or not.

content.raw:
A System can't delete entities unless we expand how systems work and are updated.

Erasing an entity is not equal to erasing a model, which would erase joints and child links for example.

The asynchronous nature of deletion is something we can't handle gracefully right now. We'd have to have long running services, like actions.
content.html:
A System can't delete entities unless we expand how systems work and are updated.

Erasing an entity is not equal to erasing a model, which would erase joints and child links for example.

The asynchronous nature of deletion is something we can't handle gracefully right now. We'd have to have long running services, like actions.

content.raw:
Why setup a whole system just for that redirection?

*Edit - forgot that I removed `EraseEntity` from  the EntityComponentManager*

A system can call `RequestEraseEntity`, so my previous statement "A System can't delete entities unless we expand how systems work and are updated." is incorrect.

Why setup a whole system just for that redirection?

Edit - forgot that I removed EraseEntity from the EntityComponentManager

A system can call RequestEraseEntity, so my previous statement "A System can't delete entities unless we expand how systems work and are updated." is incorrect.

content.raw: Because I'd expect systems to be operating on entities and components.
content.html: Because I'd expect systems to be operating on entities and components.

content.raw: Systems do not have to be the only thing operating on entities and components.
content.html: Systems do not have to be the only thing operating on entities and components.

content.raw:
So I _think_ what’s happening is:

* The entity is scheduled for removal
* The entity is removed from the entity component manager
* All components associated with the entity are removed by swapping them to the end of their corresponding storage vector and then popping them off
* Any View that contains the entity has the EraseEntity method called on it, and removes the entity from it’s internal set, as well as pointers to Components.

The issue is not with the removed entity/components, but the one that is swapped into that location.  The view is storing a `void *` to the previous location of the component, and it never gets updated \(probably should happen in `View::EraseEntity`?\), causing it to point to something off the end of the ComponentStorage internal vector.

I’ll try and work on a fix, but if you get a chance @nkoenig can you confirm that my understanding of the behvavior is correct?
content.html:
So I think what’s happening is:

  • The entity is scheduled for removal
  • The entity is removed from the entity component manager
  • All components associated with the entity are removed by swapping them to the end of their corresponding storage vector and then popping them off
  • Any View that contains the entity has the EraseEntity method called on it, and removes the entity from it’s internal set, as well as pointers to Components.

The issue is not with the removed entity/components, but the one that is swapped into that location. The view is storing a void * to the previous location of the component, and it never gets updated (probably should happen in View::EraseEntity?), causing it to point to something off the end of the ComponentStorage internal vector.

I’ll try and work on a fix, but if you get a chance @nkoenig can you confirm that my understanding of the behvavior is correct?

content.raw: That sounds correct.
content.html: That sounds correct.

content.raw: I think I can avoid the `swap`, and instead keep track of available slots (components that have been deleted).
content.html: I think I can avoid the swap, and instead keep track of available slots (components that have been deleted).

content.raw: Can't do this approach because it will cause the components to be non-contiguous in memory.
content.html: Can't do this approach because it will cause the components to be non-contiguous in memory.

content.raw: I'm now attempting to store a ComponentId, rather than a pointer to the component data in a view.
content.html: I'm now attempting to store a ComponentId, rather than a pointer to the component data in a view.
